item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote=“Rixxx, post:12, topic:368014”]Aftermath,

Thanks for suggesting, I just read and will continue to read the PircBot source. IMO the written PircBot class’s design is how a typical Moparscaper would do it. It is resemblant to the common Client class people have in their servers. Also, am I not keeping the IRC protocol intact here? I’ve referred to this site and I am handling the server’s output correctly with the commands.

Regarding the Connection class, it was only used to connect the bot to the network. It then handles input and output (like you have mentioned) in a single thread. I’ll probably use two threads for handling input and output separately, but then the threads will be running on their own. Wouldn’t that introduce inaccurate input/output handling?

I do know that the above code has portions where the stream appears not to be flushed. That is because I called the [tt]flush()[/tt] method outside of the method I was supposed to include it in (in this case, the [tt]join(String channel)[/tt] method). I’ve long rewritten that in the current bot I have.

Anyway, writing the bot was for practice. The main reason I wrote it was to have my own IRC bot with AI. I’ve abandoned the project anyway. :P[/quote]

Bump!

Read full topic

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Also, your Connection’s constructor contains an infinite loop and the logic for the connection. Constructors should just contain initialization stuff, if you want to make it do stuff give it a run method or something.

[quote=“abraham2119, post:36, topic:367942”][quote author=Aftermath link=topic=464087.msg3399352#msg3399352 date=1289768165]
Your code appears to have several points where output is written but not flushed. This will result in commands effectively being queued until something comes from the server that triggers a flush() call in your code. You should probably call flush() wherever you’re done writing.
[/quote]socket streams don’t need to be flushed…[/quote]

Actually, he has to flush. Check out this sample code done in the same style as his:

[code]import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.BufferedWriter;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;
import java.io.OutputStreamWriter;
import java.net.Socket;

public class Test {
public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
Socket s = new Socket(“mitb.moparisthebest.com”, 6667);
BufferedWriter bw = new BufferedWriter(new OutputStreamWriter(s.getOutputStream()));
BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(s.getInputStream()));

	bw.write("USER A A A: A\n");
	bw.write("NICK A\n");
	bw.flush();

	while(true) {
		String line = br.readLine();
		if(line == null) break;
		
		if(line.contains("PING")) {
			bw.write(line.replace("PING", "PONG") + "\n");
			bw.flush();
		}
		
		System.out.println(line);
	}
}

}[/code]

With the flushes commented out, this is the output:

:mitb.moparisthebest.com NOTICE AUTH :*** Looking up your hostname... :mitb.moparisthebest.com NOTICE AUTH :*** Found your hostname (cached)

But with the flushes in, it actually works.

:mitb.moparisthebest.com NOTICE AUTH :*** Looking up your hostname... :mitb.moparisthebest.com NOTICE AUTH :*** Found your hostname (cached) PING :C2D57AA2 :mitb.moparisthebest.com 001 A :Welcome to the moparisthebest IRC Network A!A@* :mitb.moparisthebest.com 002 A :Your host is mitb.moparisthebest.com, running version Unreal3.2.8.1 :mitb.moparisthebest.com 003 A :This server was created Mon Sep 20 2010 at 13:56:58 CDT :mitb.moparisthebest.com 004 A mitb.moparisthebest.com Unreal3.2.8.1 iowghraAsORTVSxNCWqBzvdHtGp lvhopsmntikrRcaqOALQbSeIKVfMCuzNTGj :mitb.moparisthebest.com 005 A UHNAMES NAMESX SAFELIST HCN MAXCHANNELS=10 CHANLIMIT=#:10 MAXLIST=b:60,e:60,I:60 NICKLEN=30 CHANNELLEN=32 TOPICLEN=307 KICKLEN=307 AWAYLEN=307 MAXTARGETS=20 :are supported by this server :mitb.moparisthebest.com 005 A WALLCHOPS WATCH=128 WATCHOPTS=A SILENCE=15 MODES=12 CHANTYPES=# PREFIX=(qaohv)~&@%+ CHANMODES=beI,kfL,lj,psmntirRcOAQKVCuzNSMTG NETWORK=moparisthebest CASEMAPPING=ascii EXTBAN=~,cqnrT ELIST=MNUCT STATUSMSG=~&@%+ :are supported by this server :mitb.moparisthebest.com 005 A EXCEPTS INVEX CMDS=KNOCK,MAP,DCCALLOW,USERIP :are supported by this server :mitb.moparisthebest.com 251 A :There are 36 users and 48 invisible on 2 servers :mitb.moparisthebest.com 252 A 8 :operator(s) online :mitb.moparisthebest.com 254 A 17 :channels formed :mitb.moparisthebest.com 255 A :I have 47 clients and 1 servers :mitb.moparisthebest.com 265 A :Current Local Users: 47 Max: 350 :mitb.moparisthebest.com 266 A :Current Global Users: 84 Max: 520 :mitb.moparisthebest.com 375 A :- mitb.moparisthebest.com Message of the Day - :mitb.moparisthebest.com 372 A :- 28/12/2009 14:42 :mitb.moparisthebest.com 372 A :- This server is operated by moparisthebest. :mitb.moparisthebest.com 372 A :- :mitb.moparisthebest.com 372 A :- Have fun! :mitb.moparisthebest.com 376 A :End of /MOTD command. :A MODE A :+iwx :Global!services@moparisthebest.com NOTICE A :[Logon News - Mar 25 2010] Welcome to Moparisthebest IRC :Global!services@moparisthebest.com NOTICE A :[Logon News - Mar 25 2010] SSL enabled on port 6697

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Aftermath, post:35, topic:367942”]Your code appears to have several points where output is written but not flushed. This will result in commands effectively being queued until something comes from the server that triggers a flush() call in your code. You should probably call flush() wherever you’re done writing.[/quote]socket streams don’t need to be flushed…

Read full topic

item.title: IRC bot [updated]
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

From a design point of view, you’d be better off parsing output from the server into the commands (JOIN, PRIVMSG, MODE) and then forwarding them to onJoin/onMessage methods. Then you can extend your Bot class with a more specialized version of those methods while leaving the IRC logic intact. I suggest you look at the PircBot source, it’s very well-designed.

Also, it looks like your Connection class is unused, so I didn’t really read through it.

Your Bot appears to handle input and output in a single thread, which is a bad idea. You should have a separate thread for input and output (or use the new IO [java.nio] to do both in a single thread, but do not use the old blocking IO in a single thread for both reading and writing).

Your code appears to have several points where output is written but not flushed. This will result in commands effectively being queued until something comes from the server that triggers a flush() call in your code. You should probably call flush() wherever you’re done writing.

Also, if you’re making a bot, you’d be better off just using PircBot as it’s already been done before (and well), but if this is just for practice, that works too. Good luck.

Read full topic
